q2.question: What is the corresponding grammar for DFA, NFA, RegEx?

q3.question: What is the corresponding grammar for PDAs?

q4.description: There are some differences in the machines.
q4.question: DFAs and NFAs are exactly the same.
q4.answer: No, DFAs are deterministic. NFAs add non-determinism, which simply means that there can be multiple choices out of a state for the same input character.
choices: No, DFAs are deterministic. NFAs add non-determinism, which simply means that there can be multiple choices out of a state for the same input character.

q5.description: There are some differences in the machines.
q5.question: What are the differences between NFA and PDA
answer: PDA has a stack for storage
choices: PDA has a stack for storage

q6.description: These machines all have some similarities
q6.question: What are the similarities between NFA and PDA
answer: They all take an input string.
They all march across the string from left to right, one character at each step.
They stop when they reach the end of the string and then make a simple decision (accept/reject
choices: They all take an input string.
They all march across the string from left to right, one character at each step.
They stop when they reach the end of the string and then make a simple decision (accept/reject

q7.description: There are some differences in the machines.
q7.question: NFA and PDA are callecd acceptors
q7.answer: Yes, all that they can do is determine if a string is a member of the language, and the “more powerful” machines can accept or reject string from more “complicated” languages.
choices: Yes, all that they can do is determine if a string is a member of the language, and the “more powerful” machines can accept or reject string from more “complicated” languages.

q8.description: But there is a lot more that we typically expect when we talk about “computation”. Like, the ability to “compute” rather than simply accept.
q8.question: Suppose that $L$ is the language of all arithmatic expressions, the input for our machine is the string $2 + 3$, which of the following is a computation?
choices: accepting the string $2 + 3$ as it is $\in L$

q13.description: $\textbf{State machines}$ are simple to understand. There are a number of different state machines, with a range of capabilities. We will discuss a particular one, called a $\textbf{Turing machine}$. As we define "capability", the key is ability, not efficiency.
q13.question: Which of the following means ability of the machine
choices: consume small amount of memory as possible

q14.description:
The necessary capabilities for any such "machine" are these:
- Read
- Write
- Compute
q14.question: What is the cabability of NFAs, DFAs, and PDAs

q2.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right. Each square can store one character. The machine has a single I/O head that at any instant in time is "on" one of the squares. The control unit of the machine is defined by a set of abstract $states$. At any given instant, the machine is said to be "in" one of the states, and has a set of actions that can be performed when in that state. From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol,
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay (S)
q2.question: Which of the following action can't a Turing Machine do?

q3.description: The letters that can appear on the tape are an important part of the definition for a given Turing machine. The alphabet of the machine is these letters that may appear in the input. In addition to the letters of the alphabet that can define an input string, there is also the blank character. When talking about strings, since a blank is hard to see, we will use the # character to represent a blank character. Note that including # in the alphabet is for convenience only. We want to be able to read our specifications without being confused.
q3.question: Which of the following definition about "#" in Turing Machine's $\textbf{string}$ is correct?
choices: Pop the letter in current state
Overwrite letter in current state with "#"
